results.title: CATARACT (concrete)
results.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
results.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

constellations_primary.name: Now watch this
constellations_primary.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.headline_credit_for_label:
Australia, 2020

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop.
results.description:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.
description_for_label:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.

results.title: Mad Max: Fury Road production still
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979–85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.

results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian filmmaker and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed features and two shorts including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian filmmaker and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed features and two shorts including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

results.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
results.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

constellations_primary.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_primary.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

results.title_for_label: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.description: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
description_for_label: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. results.title: Did you ask the river?
results.credit_line:
Joan Ross
Mordant Family VR Commission, ACMI Collection
Developed in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle at Tactical Space Lab, Sydney
results.material_description: software, video, props, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
‘Did you ask the river?’ is the debut VR work from one of Australia’s leading visual artists, Joan Ross.

In the style of a first-person videogame, participants are given free rein to explore an interactive 3D extension of Ross’s vibrant, yet unsettling, colonial landscapes.

Unlike many VR experiences, participants are placed in a body – that of an 18th century colonial woman – and become uncomfortably complicit in her unwitting destruction of the landscape.
results.description:

results.title: Perfecscope stereoscopic viewer for 1900 Paris Exposition
results.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

results.title: Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector
results.brief_description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.
The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.
The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

-Object does not have a flue
-Lens can be extended 1.8 cm
-Internal condenser lens is a later addition and does not fit well

Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector - Ebay purchase

Original listing: https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/352469927305
From listing:
This is one that has been sitting collecting dust for many years, an 1880s dated Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) magic lantern projector. It has the stenciled triangle with the 1888 date as well as “Paragon” on the front which both sides have wear but these are actually harder to find with the painted stenciled lettering on it. The reel is full but a couple of the slides are broken but still for display purposes on a shelf looks alright. The body is the blued steel look which depending on the lighting either shows the blue look or more towards black if the lighting is bad. The front lens does extend with the turn knob and also retracts. The front lens & condensor lens are good just need a proper cleaning like the rest of this. The wood base does have some scratches which if someone were to use a stain pen you could probably fix those spots up pretty quick. Overall “G” good condition as seen with wear. The rails on this one are a brass color which the later models were just nickel plated. In back is no burner which it had been electrified so that old unit was thrown away.
results.description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.

The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.

The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

results.title: The Way of the Exploding Fist
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
‘The Way of the Exploding Fist’ was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first ‘beat-‘em-up’ games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat em up. Jordan Mechner’s “Karateka”(1984) which came out just before “The Way of the Exploding Fist” was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really bringing home the sense of the combat in contrast Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack offering an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of ‘kai-ai ’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Softwares fast loader the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in “Crash” (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that “The Way of the Exploding Fist” ‘… is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]
results.description:
The Way of the Exploding Fist was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first beat-em-up games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat-em-up. Jordan Mechner’s Karateka(1984), which came out just before The Way of the Exploding Fist, was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really brings home the sense of the combat in contrast to Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack, which offers an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of “:kai-ai”’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Software’s fast-loader, the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in Crash (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that The Way of the Exploding Fist “is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/

Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

Our version of the game is playable on Commodore 64 and Commodore 128.
description_for_label:
The Way of the Exploding Fist was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first beat-em-up games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat-em-up. Jordan Mechner’s Karateka(1984), which came out just before The Way of the Exploding Fist, was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really brings home the sense of the combat in contrast to Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack, which offers an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of “:kai-ai”’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Software’s fast-loader, the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in Crash (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that The Way of the Exploding Fist “is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/
